Feature: Are there specific vocabularies for hunting or use in the presence of avoidance kin?
Is there ritual speech?
Comment: There is a long answer about how to organize marriage but no answer about the ritual speech. Check Steinhauer's work.

Feature: Does the ritual speech involve parallellisms, dual symbolic categories?
Comment: Check Steinhauer's work.

Feature: Is the ritual language known by everyone (or just by traditional leaders)?
Comment: Clip 7, 9:20

Feature: Are there ritual songs?
Are there ritual dances?
Comment: Lego-lego is dari. They dance in a circle, men and women together, holding each other's little fingers. Closer contact is not allowed.

Feature: Is the language of the ritual songs a language you understand?
Is the language of the ritual songs a foreign language?
Do women and men dance together?
Are there traditional ceremonies where men and women must be separated?
Is there a ceremony relating to planting/harvesting?
Comment: Harvesting of kacang (beans): we sit in a circle together to peel them, and sing together doing a game. (No example is given.)

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive in boats?
Comment: We just came from Pantar, with boats. These boats had sides made of coconut leafs because otherwise the waves would get in. This island was first a vulcano, about 500 years ago (we heard from somone at Udayana University in Bali).

Feature: Does sacrifice involve feeding of ancestors?
Comment: We do not sacrifice to the ancestors (as we are christians now). The question is asked twice in clip 8 (in different contexts) and both times answered negatively. In a neighbouring group there is however a ritual feeding the ancestors: when something bad happens (theft, etc.) food is sacrificed on a special rock so that the person who did the sin will be punished.

Feature: Is there/are  there (a) ritual place(s)?
Comment: There are several places in the  ritual: the place with the round stone here, where there is crying; and a place a bit away from here, at a stream called ribusari, where they must be silent, they are not allowed to scream and shout (or else there will be no rain). There is also another sacred place, a rock in the shape of a human, called Wenibau where rotan grows, but we are not allowed to cut that rotan.

Feature: Did your ancestors arrive as sea animals? (shark, crocodile, turtle, dolphin)
Is there a myth about the origin of the people?
Are there traditional religious leaders or specialists?
Are there traditional drinks, or stimulants?
Comment: Tuak owa 'tuak mentah (unprocessed lontar palm sap)', arak 'distilled tuak'.

Feature: Is there a traditional sacrifice place?
Are there rituals around birth?
Comment: There is no ritual befor or after birth. In other places they have rituals, but here we don't. The only thing is that the baby should be kept in the house for 40 days (but the mother can go out).

Feature: Are there rituals around death?
Comment: Mete: watch the body for one or two nights, and we sing together, using guitars. Then the body is buried and we say a prayer. That's it. 40 days after the burial we have a sembayang syukur, a thanksgiving, with a meal for everybody. We slaughter a pig, a goat and eat fish. But on the day of the burial we have no ceremonies or clebrations. Elsewhere in Alor they do have ceremonies but here we don't, because it's just bikin rugi orang.On New Year's day we used to go to the graves of the dead in a procession with gongs, and spray flowers on the graves (clip 9: 9:00).

Feature: Are there seasonal rituals apart from planting and harvesting, for example is there a ritual to ask for rain? Or other rituals?
Comment:
When we want to plant, we bring seeds to church, and pray for a good crop. (clip 8; 6:31)
There is a flat, round stone, called bantalu. It also has a child (small stone belonging with it).  With one child there will be no rain. So we have to bring young coconut to go with it. The ritual takes place at night. All the lights and lamps in the village must be off and no-one is allowed to go out of the house. Then two men go naked, the run around in the village, crying, calling for rain.

Feature: Do women traditionally weave?
Comment: Yes, but they are newcomers, e.g. a Reta woman, and a woman from Timor (Oecussi) people. Here we are busy with tuak: the husband taps it from the trees, the wife cooks it to become sopi. In another part of the interview he mentions that women also make niru, flat baskets to clean rice, to sell in the market.

Feature: Is there traditional pottery?
Comment: There is no clay here, just rocks.

Feature: Are there moko?
Comment: Those who have many daughters, will have moko. They are kept at people's home, not at a special rumah adat nor at the ketua adat.

Feature: Is it allowed to exchange the moko?
Comment: They are used as bride price. But they can be sold if there is a need. This is why there are only few moko left here.

Feature: Are there people who make new moko?
Are there traditional music instruments?
Comment: There is a kind of small anklung like instrument that is used by Reta people called kediding. But we have no special music instruments.

Feature: Are there particular traditional music styles?
Comment: With lego-lego we use gongs.

Feature: Do people use body paint or tattoo?
Comment: In the past, someone who got a skin disease (e.g. penyakit kudis) would tattoo around the spot to stop it from spreading. Tattoo was not used as adornment.

Feature: Were teeth traditionally filed? (i.e. made shorter with a file)
Comment: Using batang aur (a kind of bamboo), teeth were filed. You were only allowed to touch a woman's breast after your teeth had been filed. Teeth filing is sign of adulthood.

Feature: Are there typical traditional haircuts?
Traditional piercings?
Comment: For women only.

Feature: Are feathers or beads used as adornments?
Is there traditional jewelry?
Comment: In the past we used bells on legs and arms when we lego-lego (gilang = giring-giring). Nowadays we don't have these anymore.

Feature: Is there special adornment used in rituals or ceremonies?
Comment: Women and men must wear sarongs when we lego-lego. (Men and women can wear the same kind of sarongs, unlike in Reta where they wear separate kind of things.)  Apart from that there are no adornments.

Feature: Is spatial organization divided into primary and secondary type?
Comment: East: weden da 'sun rise', West: wed bang 'sun goes down'. North and South: difficult, we don't know, we just use Utara and Selatan.

Feature: Are there conceptual connections between spatial directions such as E+S / W + N with male/female, or with day/night, or with right/left?
Do adults in this village typically speak more than one local language?
Do children typically speak more than one local language?
Comment: Many children (probably 75%) now speak Indonesian, but actually they do not really understand it as well as the local language.

Feature: Is it common in this village that husband and wife have different languages?
Comment: There are some mixed languages, but after a year or two, the newcomer who married a Pura person learns to speak the local language.

Feature: Does a wife learn to speak the language of her husband?
Comment: The majority of newcomers are women w who marry a Pura husband. They learn the local language.

Feature: Does a husband learn to speak the language of his wife?
Comment: There are a few cases where a man from another island marries with a Pura woman and lives on Pura. He must learn the local language too.

Feature: Do they communicate with a third language?
Comment: Maybe in the beginning, but after a while they usually also speak Pura together.

Feature: Do people traditionally hunt?
Comment: Mostly people in the other part of the village ("Dusun B"). In this village only about 2% of the men still hunt (3-4 out of ~200). They use bow and arrow, no spear. They hunt pigs and deer.

Feature: Do people traditionally fish in the sea?
Comment: They use fish traps (oval or rectangular shape) made of bamboo. Fish nets are also used, but traps are more traditional. Some also use a 'kompresor' to dive deep and spear fish.

Feature: Do people traditionally have animal husbandry?
Comment: Pigs, goats, chicken, ducks (few), dogs, cats. Everyone, 100%

Feature: Do people traditionally have agriculture?
Comment: There is little space for gardens on Pura. Two households work together on one plot. The crop they eat themselves, it is not sold. Crop is e.g. beans (kacang) (clip 7; 12:30)

Feature: Intensity of cultivation?
Major crops?
Comment: No rice or tubers, very few fruit trees. Jambu en kemiri trees do grow but not very many. The most important source of income is to get tuak (palm wine) from the lontar tree, which they cook to become sopi (palm liquor).

Feature: Are there clans?
Comment: The following clans are listed: Serambanang ('beggars'), Molidopal (?), Adobalolu ('bubungan rumah yg paling tinggi'), Lokamboru (?), Wed Hawa ('sun house'), Tabu Hawa ('siput house'), Lit Hawa ('rock house'), Baku Malung, Deng Wa (people from the Malal clan in the south who moved here), Marang Hawa ('angry house'), Bial Etang ('on top of the elang').

Feature: Are there moieties?
Comment: A marga is described as a family consisting of several brothers and their offspring. The following moieties are listed: Wenigomang, Taramahi, Pekomo, Gomang Dopung, Dopung Nuha, Halajahi, Salamahi, Pasmahi, Nuhomo, Lapikoli, Mobubung, Ilduka, Nuaholong, Olang (came from Pantar), Sengaji, Dopongabora, Puling Wetang, Tonum Puling, Watang Halung, Wetang Gomang, Kandola, Kiarutang, Mukolang, Aborawatang, Doponduru, Pulamau, Jahidopong, Pasutung, Hamapu, Wenidata, Lumba, Manupas, Pasmarang, Deni. Many clans divide into moieties but it is mentioned that there are also moieties whose members come from different clans.

Feature: Is there a concept of 'house' (uma/rumah) that equals a descent group?
Comment: The word hawa used in some of the clan names translates as 'house'. In the past, each clan had its own house, with a separate section for each family or moiety. They alll lived in one big house.

Feature: Are clans matrilineal
Are clans, subclans or lineages ranked
Comment: For example, in the Molidopal clan, there are three levels of moyeties/families: 1. Nuhomo, the leader/eldest of the clan, 2. Teramahi, 3. Halajahi. Not all moyeties in a clan actually have a traditional location, some come from outside the area. From outside the area can also become head of clan.

Feature: Does every clan speak their own language?
Is real property (land) inherited?
Comment: The ancestors divided the land. This is inherited from father to son. If a person does not own land, he can also rent it, and use it to grow crops, but that land or the right to rent it is not inheritable.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: It is inherited by the sons in the family. The son who stays at home to look after the house (and does not get an education) will be the one to organise what to do with the heritage.

Feature: Did one person (lord / clan) originally own all the land?
Comment: In the past, much of the land here was owned by the Nuhomo family.

Feature: Are there inheritance rules?
Comment: Only sons inherit, as daughters are moving out of the clan into their husband's.

Feature: Is land inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is land inheritance patrilineal (sons)?
Is moveable property inheritance matrilineal (sister's sons; sister's younger brother)?
Is moveable property inheritance patrilineal?
Do all children inherit, sons and daughters alike?
Do all children inherit, with daughters receiving less?
Can newcomers aquire land or gardens?
Comment: Newcomers are given land to build a house on or to make a garden. They can also work together on land owned by an original inhabitant. But they cannot buy land. Land is never sold / bought here. Then he explains that in the 1960's when there was a famine, his father bought land with kacang jagung.But that land was taken back again.

Feature: At what age should young people get married?
Comment: girls: 25; boys: 30. There are women here who have not married, and stay with their parents, because their bride price was too high.

Feature: Are there marriage rules – specify in notes field
Comment: A man marries his FS daughter. [check kinship chart: also MB son?]. When the woman marries a man in a different village, a bride price has to be negotiated. But when the marriage is inside our village, we discuss the marriage but no actual objects are negotiated.

Feature: Is there gift exchange between bride's and groom's sides?
Comment: The bride's side can bring corn, goats, pigs etc for consumption at the wedding.

Feature: Is there bride service?
Comment: It is possible that a man moves in with the family of his wife ('kawin masuk') when there are no sons in that family. The couple is still part of the man's clan but they live with the bride's parents.(clip 4, 4 mins). There is no bride service (unlike in Sumba, as is explicitly mentioned). Here, we are told to work so that we have a bride price, before we marry. If the bride price is not paid, it will become a debt. If in that famly there is a younger brother who wants to get married, then the groom with the debt must pay his brother in law's bride price.

Feature: Transfer of residence at marriage?
Comment: The wife leaves her home, and is accompanied to her new home by the husband's group, with a procession with gongs and drums. We first dance around the mount of stones three times and then accompany her to her new home.

Feature: Marital residence with kin?
Are traditional marriages obligatorily exogamous?
If mother dies, who raises the children?
Comment: When the father gets a new wife, the new wife moves in with him and the children remain with their father and new wife.
Possible Values: 12:Father and his family.;10:Father and/or his family;11:Mother and/or her family

Feature: Does a man typically marry a woman of his mother's subclan?
Does a woman typicaly marry a man of her father’s subclan?
Are there locality-based restrictions on marriage
Was polygamy permitted
Was polyandry permitted?
Is bridewealth paid by the groom's side to the bride's side
Is dowry paid by the bride's side to the groom's side
Comment: The bride's parents do not pay but the bride's MB is the pohon pelepas so he ikut menangis when the bride leaves the family. He must provide a closet/cupboard (to keep clothes in), a bed, a mattress, cooking stuff,a tempat sirih pinang and other furniture for the household.

Feature: Are villages the typical settlement pattern?
Are dispersed solitary family homesteads the typical settlement pattern?
Are settlements permanent?
Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related women
Mean size of local communities?
Comment: 1098 households including newcomers

Feature: Are villages/hamlets centered on a group of related men?
Are villages/hamlets (traditionally) located on hill tops?
Are villages/hamlets (tradtionally) located on the shore?
Do villages have places or spaces for gatherings?
Comment: 1: the area around the church, 2. a communitiy center, 3. the circular mount of stones (if there is a tree we can also have discussions there).

Feature: Shape of (traditional) houses?
Comment: We do not have a rumah adat here anymore. We had one in the old village.

Feature: Floor level of traditional houses?
Shape of roof of traditional houses?
Is there an attic or loft in a traditional house?
Comment: On the first floor, every family has its own cooking/living space. In the loft, food is kept. Traditional barang adat is also kept there, if it is the house of the clan's leader. But nowadays, there is no barang adat left.

Feature: Do leaders come from particular lineages?
Comment: In the  past, leaders had to be from the Nuhomo clan. Nowadays, that is no longer required. If a Nuhomo leader has a child that 'can talk', he can become the leader, but if the child is 'dumb', someone else who 'can talk' can become the leader. 'Can talk' means: who knows the traditional words and rules.

Feature: Are leaders non-hereditary?
Comment: Wealth is not important; experience and knowledge of traditional rules is important.

Feature: Are there groups with whom traditional relations are forbidden?
Are there groups with whom there has been war?
Comment: But there is a tradition where we hit ourselves with rotan on our legs, with gong music, when we finished making the roof of a house. It is called 'wash hands/body'. After that there is karate between villages, with gongs.

Feature: Is there an opposition between people of the interior and people of the shore?
Are there female community/clan leaders
Comment: It is possible but it has not happened yet that a woman sits with the men to discuss adat. But it can be made possible.

Feature: Are there men’s houses
Are there (traditional)   rulers/kings?
Comment: clip 6, 1:50

Feature: Are there slaves?
Comment: clip 6, 1:50

Feature: Is there a concept for both ruler and foreigner, stranger king?
Are there traditional relations/alliances with one or more neighbouring groups?
Comment: Istilah bela ko, di sini tidak ada.(Clip 6, 3:29 mins). The Blagar in Pantar have it with the people in Lembata.

Feature: Is there a special name for this alliance?
Is namesake ritually marked, or with features reminiscent of particular kinship relations?
Comment: After 2 months, the baby is given a name. The baby can then go out of the house. The mother however can go out of the house immediately after birth. Names of people that are still alive can be given. (clip 10, 10:15 mins.)
Possible Values: 10:Given Abui name upon birth given by  parents;0:No;1:Yes

Feature: Do descent groups own sets of personal names?
Are names taken from the father's group?
Comment: Names are free, taken from the Bible, or Michael Jackson, or the month when the baby is born.

Feature: Are names taken from the mother's group?
Are there name taboos?
Comment: Names of people that are still alive can be given. (clip 10, 10:15 mins.) But in the past that was forbidden (clip 10, 13 mins)

Feature: Are there particular relations not to be addressed, or mentioned, by name
Comment: Older people cannot be called by their first name. Surname or full name must be preceded by boma (men), meme (women). (clip 7, beginning), or nimang 'my father', niva 'my mother'

Feature: did your language (or a group of people defined by speaking the language) traditionally have a name, other than a locality name
Is there a special word to refer to a foreigner?
